scientific.overview: Root rot is a fungal disease primarily caused by Pythium, Phytophthora, or Rhizoctonia species. Treatment focuses on removing affected tissue, improving drainage, and applying fungicides.

steps.title: Remove from pot and inspect roots
steps.details: Carefully remove the plant from its container. Inspect all roots thoroughly. Healthy roots should be white or light tan and firm. Diseased roots will be brown, black, soft, or slimy.

steps.title: Cut away diseased roots
steps.details: Using sterilized pruning shears or scissors, cut away all soft, mushy, or discolored roots. Cut at least 1 inch above any visible damage to ensure complete removal of infected tissue. Sterilize tools with rubbing alcohol between cuts.

steps.title: Apply fungicide to remaining roots
steps.details: Dust or spray remaining healthy roots with a broad-spectrum fungicide containing copper sulfate or thiophanate-methyl. Follow product label instructions for dilution rates.

steps.title: Allow roots to dry
steps.details: Leave the plant out of soil for 2-3 days in a shaded, well-ventilated area. This allows cut surfaces to callus over and prevents reinfection.

steps.title: Repot in fresh, well-draining soil
steps.details: Use a commercial cactus/succulent mix or create your own with 2 parts potting soil, 1 part coarse sand, and 1 part perlite. Ensure the new pot has drainage holes. Do not use old soil.

steps.title: Adjust watering schedule
steps.details: Water only when the top 2-3 inches of soil are completely dry. Reduce watering frequency by 30-50% compared to previous routine. Ensure excess water drains freely.

scientific.dosage_frequency: Fungicide application: Follow product label. Typical is one application during repotting. Preventive sprays can be applied monthly during growing season.
safety_warnings: Wear gloves when handling fungicides and diseased plant material
Wash hands thoroughly after handling infected plants
Keep fungicides away from children and pets
Do not compost diseased plant material - dispose in trash
Sterilize all tools and pots before reuse
when_to_consult_expert: More than 70% of roots are affected
Disease returns after treatment within 2 months
Multiple plants in your collection show symptoms
Plant shows no improvement after 4-6 weeks
You are unsure about proper fungicide selection

citations.title: Management of Pythium Root Rot in Ornamental Plants
citations.snippet: Removing infected roots and improving drainage are critical first steps. Fungicide application should target Pythium and Phytophthora species.

citations.title: Root Rot Diseases in Succulent Plants
citations.snippet: Aloe species are particularly susceptible to waterlogging. A well-draining substrate with at least 40% inorganic matter significantly reduces incidence.

ayurvedic.overview: In Ayurvedic plant care, root rot represents an imbalance of water element (Jala). Treatment uses natural antifungal herbs and emphasizes restoring balance through proper drainage and traditional remedies.

steps.title: Remove plant and trim damaged roots
steps.details: Gently remove the plant and examine roots. Use a clean blade to remove all soft, darkened roots. This removes Ama (toxins) from the plant system.

steps.title: Apply neem and turmeric paste
steps.details: Mix 2 tablespoons neem powder with 1 teaspoon turmeric powder and enough water to make a paste. Apply to cut root surfaces. Both ingredients have natural antifungal properties (Krimighna).

steps.title: Dry in shade with airflow
steps.details: Place plant in a shaded, airy location for 2-3 days. This follows the Ayurvedic principle of Ruksha (drying) to remove excess moisture element.

steps.title: Prepare medicated soil mixture
steps.details: Mix regular potting soil with coarse sand, neem cake powder (1 cup per gallon of soil), and dried holy basil (Tulsi) leaves. This creates a Tridosha-balancing medium.

steps.title: Repot and water with herbal solution
steps.details: Plant in the prepared mixture. For first watering, use water infused with neem leaves and cinnamon bark (both boiled and cooled). This provides Pitta-balancing properties.

steps.title: Maintain Vata-balancing watering schedule
steps.details: Water only when soil is dry to touch. Follow lunar cycles - water during waxing moon for growth, reduce during waning moon. Add diluted neem water monthly.

ayurvedic.dosage_frequency: Neem-turmeric paste: Single application. Neem water: 1:20 dilution, monthly. Herbal watering solution: Only for first watering after repotting.
safety_warnings: Test neem paste on small root section first to check sensitivity
Avoid neem in extreme heat - may cause stress
Pregnant women should avoid handling neem preparations
Keep herbal preparations away from children and pets
when_to_consult_expert: Plant shows no improvement after 4 weeks of Ayurvedic treatment
Root damage exceeds 70% of root system
You observe unusual reactions to herbal treatments
Disease spreads to other plants despite preventive measures
You need guidance on authentic Ayurvedic preparation methods

citations.title: Ayurvedic Approach to Plant Disease Management
citations.source: Journal of Ayurveda and Integrative Medicine, 2019
citations.snippet: Neem (Azadirachta indica) and turmeric (Curcuma longa) demonstrate broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity through multiple phytochemical pathways.

citations.title: Traditional Indian Plant Protection Methods
citations.snippet: The Krimighna (antimicrobial) properties of neem have been documented in classical texts like Charaka Samhita, with modern studies confirming antifungal efficacy.
